results.title: The Mother
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “The Australian eye III”.
Life and paintings of George W. Lambert, flamboyant Australian war artist, painter and poet, including the important painting “The Mother”. Talks of how he encouraged young painters including Roland Wakelin and Grace Cossington Smith and his involvement as a war artist and memorial sculptor. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Mosquito
results.brief_description: The lifecycle of the mosquito, its breeding places, eggs, larvae, pupa, and the final stage. Methods used to combat the spread of mosquitoes are shown in detail.

results.title: The Moselle: a victory for Europe
results.brief_description: On May 24, 1964, the new waterway on the river Moselle, an important step towards European economic unity, was inaugurated. It connects the iron ore deposits of the Lorraine and the Saar, and the Ruhr Valley with the Belgian-Dutch coalmines. Shows the picturesque landscape of the Moselle area.

results.title: The Morris Gleitzman video
results.creator_credit: Mark Waters, Christine McCaul Gleitzman and Insight Profile
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Insight profile”.
Unbeknownst to readers of Morris Gleitzman, he has a ghost co-writer, an 11 year-old version of himself who resides within and provides inspiration for his novels. He can’t write without him and he can’t be forced out. Gleitzman explains how daydreaming assists with the ideas process and provides examples of the inspiration behind “Misery Guts” and other novels. He also addresses the ambiance of his environs and how it can influence his writing, including the layout of the desk and his passion for stationery. Character development, discovering the story and the research process leading up to the process of writing the first chapter is also discussed. Morris talks of childhood aspirations, literary influences, and the path that led to his first novel, “The Other facts of life”. He also discusses the editorial process, the role of his agent, and the business side of supporting himself as a writer.

results.title: The Morning star painter
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy, Australia Council and Curtis Levy Productions
results.brief_description: A film about an Aboriginal family who live in Arnhem Land in the Northern Territory. Jack Wunuwun is a tribal elder and a well known painter and this film records him making a bark painting depicting the legend of the morning star. Bark paintings and woven baskets, that are done by the family, are taken into Darwin to be sold. Narrated and with music by David Gulpilil.

results.title: The Morgan experience
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Porter, Castrol and PP Video Productions
results.brief_description: Brian Weeks has been driving and filming Morgans for over 25 years. This video is the result of this experience and covers a broad range of areas such as; footage from Morgans in action at Le Mans, the evolution and construction of the vehicles, associated motor clubs, buying, maintaining and restoring, 3 wheeler Morgans, Morgans in the United States, interviews with Peter and Charles Morgan, plus much more.

results.title: The More things change (NP)
results.creator_credit: Mark Davis, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Everybody’s business: management in action (NP)”.
This episode looks at the pervasiveness of change, how to plan for change, why change is resisted and the relationship between learning and change. Change is a process that must begin with individuals.

results.title: The Moontrap
results.creator_credit: Marcel Carriere, Michel Brault, Pierre Perrault, Fernand Dansereau, Jacques Bobet and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The moon is still held to influence the earth and the souls of the dead are thought to help catch white whales. On I’lle-aux-Coudres, a small island in the St. Lawrence, the inhabitants (for centuries) trapped white beluga whales by sinking a corral of 3,990 saplings into offshore mud at low tide. After 1920, the practice was abandoned. This is the unrehearsed story of what happened when old-timers of the island were persuaded to revive the practice. Cinematography, Michel Brault, Bernard Gosselin. Narration, Stanley Jackson. Editing, Werner Nold. Sound, Marcel Carriere, Pierre Lemelin. Music, Jean Cousineau, Jean Meunier. (Eight Awards, including Canadian Film Awards; Melbourne; Toronto.)

results.title: The Mooncalf
results.creator_credit: Keiran Weir, Jan Rockford and AFTRS
results.brief_description: After seeing Allan (Tony Harvey) in hospital the viewer is taken through some disjointed scenes that describe Allan, his social life, community life and friends from a small seaside South Australian town. More deeply, the film goes to describe the violence that underpins Australian society and particularly the Australian youth culture. After leaving the hospital with brain damage, Allan soon discovers that the stigma of his injuries doesn’t win him many friends and in fact ostracizes him from his social group. The cowardice that is synonymous with violent behaviour is tackled here, best exampled by his ‘mate’ Darryl (Paul Gleeson) who provides light on the meaning of ‘mateship’ understood in this social group. Although Allan sees life differently there is no hope or means of escape, he always seems to see things when it’s too late. Written and directed by Keiran Weir.
